container-title: For T.H.Green, see Harris and Morrow’s edition of his Lectures on the Principles of Political Obligation (1986), and M.Richter, The Politics of Conscience: T.H.Green and his Age (1964). Part VII REACTIONS TO LIBERALISM 1: HEGEL—THE STATE AND DIALECTIC
title: Spencer’s politics makes easier reading now than his large volumes on psychology and sociology. The latest edition of The Man Versus the State is Mack and Nock
Herbert Spencer on Evolution
is a useful collection. Peel’s Herbert Spencer: The Evolution of a Sociologist (1992), is an excellent intellectual biography

container-title: and S.Avineri, Hegel’s Theory of the Modern State (1972), are outstanding commentaries. C.Taylor
is good, knockabout stuff. Part VIII REACTIONS TO LIBERALISM 2: SOCIALISM
Karl Popper, The Open Society and its Enemies
title: T.M.Knox (1942 and various reprintings), is essential reading, especially the Preface. Duncan Forbes’s edition of the Lectures on the Philosophy of World History (1975) contains an excellent introduction. There is a useful collection of Hegel’s Political writings
Reason and Revolution: Hegel and the Rise of Social Theory (1963
is also first-rate
is a very good introduction

container-title: Also to be read are Jose Antonio Primo de Rivera, Selected Writings
A.Lyttleton (1973), and The French Right: From De Maistre to Maurras
title: It is perhaps surprising that the works of fascist thinkers are not that readily available in English, and there is room for much speculation on why this is the case
For Hitler, see A.Bullock
J.P.Stern, The Führer and the People
I.Kershaw, Hitler
For a general treatment of fascism, see E.Nolte, Three Faces of Fascism
which has been the source of much debate. For an idea of the range of commentary on fascism, see W.Lacqueur, Fascism: A Reader’s Guide
original, and, like all originals, invites imitators only at their peril

container-title: Some Maurras is available in J.S.McClelland

E.Weber, Action française (1962), and R.Remond, The Right in France from 1815 to de Gaulle (1966), are standard. Oakeshott’s Experience and its Modes (1933), is not easy to read. His Rationalism in Politics and Other Essays
note: and On Human Conduct (1975), are easy to read but not always easy to understand.
title: Maurras’s Enquête sur la monarchie is one of the few great political works never to have been translated into English
The French Right: From De Maistre to Maurras
M.Curtis, Three Against the Third Republic
is a good place to start
coming of age 436–64; elitist critique of 620–38; enemies of 640–60; foundations of 232–5; maturity and decline 478–500
as critique of capitalism and political economy 538–42; Index 787 and the Engels problem 554–6; Hegelian context 518–21; Russian 569–93; and the state 544–5
